meta_data.title: Reinforced Dynamic Adversarial Training Framework for Traffic Forecasting Models
affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Example
Department of Electrical Engineering, Institute of Example
meta_data.abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for adversarial training specifically designed for spatiotemporal traffic forecasting models. Recognizing the limitations of static defense strategies in dynamic environments, the proposed method employs reinforcement learning to dynamically select adversarial samples, enhancing robustness against adversarial attacks with minimal overfitting. Furthermore, a self-knowledge distillation strategy addresses the 'forgetting issue' during training by transferring knowledge from previous epochs. Evaluation on real-world datasets demonstrates that this approach significantly boosts adversarial robustness, crucial for the effectiveness and reliability of Intelligent Transportation Systems.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This research introduces a dynamic adversarial training framework aimed at bolstering the robustness of traffic forecasting models against spatiotemporal adversarial attacks. By integrating reinforcement learning and self-knowledge distillation, this method adeptly tackles the adversarial robustness challenges faced by traditional defense strategies.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To combat the vulnerability of spatiotemporal traffic forecasting models to adversarial attacks by developing a tailored adversarial training framework.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Existing adversarial training methods falter in dynamic environments like traffic forecasting, where static defense strategies are inadequate.
high_level_summary.method summary: This work employs reinforcement learning for dynamic adversarial node selection and incorporates self-knowledge distillation to mitigate knowledge forgetting during adversarial training.
high_level_summary.conclusion: Our framework successfully enhances model robustness, outperforming traditional methods in experiments on real-world datasets, confirming its potential for Intelligent Transportation Systems.

Method.description: A dynamic approach to adversarial training in spatiotemporal models, leveraging reinforcement learning for adversarial node selection and knowledge distillation for training stability.

Experiments.evaluation metric: Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)
Experiments.results: The proposed framework shows marked improvement in adversarial robustness and model stability compared to baselines across varying adversarial attacks.

conclusion.summary: The proposed adversarial training framework, leveraging reinforcement learning and knowledge distillation, effectively enhances model robustness in traffic forecasting applications, demonstrating significant improvements over existing methods in dynamic adversarial environments.
